Author: SecretFinn
Text: What nowandloud said, legally they cannot demand to know your health history or discriminate against you in the hiring process, it falls under the protection of disability law I believe. You don't owe them anything except a "yes, I am capable of fulfilling these responsibilities". Unless of course, you really feel that you won't be able to, but I suspect that's not the case since you decided to apply.  It's sort of the same trap as when employers ask "do you have reliable transportation" - they are trying to find out whether you own a car, but legally they can't ask this. If you say "Oh I ride the bus, but it's usually reliable", you've fallen into the trap. All you need to say is "yes I do".  They're looking for you to volunteer information they aren't allowed to ask for directly. Don't give it to them. If you're healthy enough, just sign it!

Author: nowandloud
Text: Sounds less like it's asking if you have any health issues and more like it's asking if you having those issues will impede your ability to complete the program successfully. Will having an ED/depression/anxiety cause you issues in reaching that goal? If not, I doubt they'd have grounds to rescind the invitation even if they knew about it.
